sentences: Harvard-MIT Division of Health Sciences and Technology

☐ Epithelial tumors: Serous, mucinous, endometrioid, clear cell, Brenner-transitional cell, mixed mesodermal, and undifferentiated tumors are considered epithelial tumors and account for approximately 70% of all ovarian neoplasms.
☐ Stromal tumors: Approximately 5% to 10% of all ovarian neoplasms are derived from ovarian stromal cells.
These include granulosa stromal cell tumor, Sertoli stromal cell tumor, sex cord tumor with annular tubules, Leydig cell tumor, lipid cell tumor, and gynandroblastoma.
☐ Germ cell tumors: Approximately 15% to 20% of all ovarian neoplasms are of germ cell origin.
This includes dysgerminoma, endodermal sinus tumor, embryonal carcinoma, polyembryoma, choriocarcinoma, teratoma, mixed forms, and gonadoblastoma.
☐ Metastatic tumors: Approximately 5% of ovarian malignancies are metastatic, most commonly from the breast or bowel.
☐ Other: A small but significant number of ovarian "neoplasms" result from ovarian soft tissue or nonneoplastic processes.

[LIST_ITEM] Bilateral in only about 10% of cases
[LIST_ITEM] Right-sided hydrothorax in association with this tumor = Meig's Syndrome
[LIST_ITEM] Presence of a benign pelvic tumor (almost always an ovarian fibroma), ascites, and a pleural effusion (usually right-sided)
[LIST_ITEM] Disappearance of the ascites and effusion after removal of the tumor
[LIST_ITEM] Due to transudation of edema fluid from the surface of the tumor
[LIST_ITEM] Due to hemorrhage within a normal corpus luteum
[LIST_ITEM] Histologically shows dark red-black hemorrhagic region surrounded by a thin rim of yellow corpus luteum
[LIST_ITEM] Ovary is dark and enlarged from hemorrhage following torsion
[LIST_ITEM] Torsion is uncommon but may occur in adults in conjunction with benign ovarian cysts or neoplasms
[LIST_ITEM] Presentation like that of acute appendicitis
[LIST_ITEM] Lined by epithelium that is serous or mucinous
[LIST_ITEM] Serous cystadenoma filled with pale yellow serous fluid in only a single cavity
[LIST_ITEM] Mucinous tumors are filled with sticky mucin and tend to be multiloculated
[LIST_ITEM] Benign epithelial ovarian tumors are bilateral in about 20% of cases
[LIST_ITEM] The inner surface is for the most part smooth
[LIST_ITEM] Many papillations on the inner surface
[LIST_ITEM] Often no early signs or symptoms with masses in the ovary
[LIST_ITEM] many ovarian tumors have metastasized by the time they are detected
[LIST_ITEM] Characteristically spread by "seeding" along peritoneal surfaces
[LIST_ITEM] Treated as though they could be
[LIST_ITEM] Microscopically - papillary projections of epithelium extending into the lumen
[LIST_ITEM] No invasion of the stroma or capsule
[LIST_ITEM] Effective screening for ovarian cancer in the general population is not yet possible.
[LIST_ITEM] Genetic tests can be performed to detect hereditary ovarian cancer syndrome (BRCA1 and BRCA2). These tests identify patients more likely to benefit from ovarian cancer screening.
[LIST_ITEM] Decreasing a patient's risk for ovarian cancer is possible through the use of oral contraceptives, prophylactic oophorectomy, and possibly tubal ligation.

[LIST_ITEM] Follow-up observation for patients who have undergone surgery and chemotherapy for primary ovarian cancer includes rectovaginal pelvic examination and CA-125 testing every 3 to 4 months for the first 2 years, with a decrease in frequency in subsequent years.
[LIST_ITEM] Epithelial ovarian carcinoma is the second most common cancer of the female reproductive tract
[LIST_ITEM] The leading cause of death from gynecologic malignancies in the United States
[LIST_ITEM] 15,000 die of it in that time
[LIST_ITEM] annual lifetime risk for ovarian cancer in US is 1.4 per 100 women
[LIST_ITEM] Wide variation in global incidence rates for ovarian carcinoma
[LIST_ITEM] Highest rates are observed in Scandinavia, Israel, and North America,
[LIST_ITEM] Lowest rates are observed in developing countries and Japan
[LIST_ITEM] Epithelial ovarian carcinoma develops sporadically in more than 95% of patients
[LIST_ITEM] Variable most strongly associated with it is family history
[LIST_ITEM] (1992) Nonstatistically significant increased risk among nulliparous women with clinical diagnoses of infertility
[LIST_ITEM] (1994) Increase in ovarian cancer among a cohort of infertile women
[LIST_ITEM] Both studies suggest a higher risk for women with infertility that results from an ovulation related cause

|  Stage I | Growth limited to the ovaries  | | --- | --- | |  Stage IA | Growth limited to one ovary; no ascites  | |   | No tumor on the external surfaces; capsules intact  | |  Stage IB | Growth limited to both ovaries; no ascites  | |   | No tumor on the external surfaces; capsules intact  | |  Stage IC | Tumor either stage IA or IB, but with tumor on surface of one or both ovaries; or with capsule ruptured; or with ascites containing malignant cells; or with positive peritoneal washings  | |  Stage II | Growth involving one or both ovaries with pelvic extension  | |  Stage IIA | Extension or metastases to the uterus or tubes  | |  Stage IIB | Extension to other pelvic tissues  | |  Stage IIC | Tumor either IIA or IIB but on the surface of one or both ovaries; or with capsule(s) ruptured; or with ascites containing malignant cells; or with positive peritoneal washings  | |  Stage III | Tumor involving one or both ovaries with peritoneal implants outside the pelvis or positive retroperitoneal or inguinal nodes; superficial liver metastasis equals stage III; tumor is limited to the true pelvis, but there is histologically proven malignant extension to small bowel or omentum  | | --- | --- |

|  Stage IIIA | Tumor grossly limited to the true pelvis with negative nodes but with histologically confirmed microscopic seeding of abdominal peritoneal surfaces  | | --- | --- | |  Stage IIIB | Tumor involving one or both ovaries with histologically confined implants of abdominal peritoneal surfaces, none exceeding 2 cm in diameter; nodes are negative  | |  Stage IIIC | Abdominal implants larger than 2 cm in diameter or positive retroperitoneal or inguinal nodes  | |  Stage IV | Growth involving one or both ovaries with distant metastases; if pleural effusion is present, there must be positive cytology to categorize as stage IV  |
[H1] INTRAOPERATIVE FINDINGS CONSISTENT WITH INVASIVE OVARIAN MALIGNANCY.
[LIST_ITEM] Usually occur in children and young adults
[LIST_ITEM] May not be discovered until later in life
[LIST_ITEM] After the menopause in rare cases
[LIST_ITEM] Composed of tissues derived from usually all three germ cell layers
[LIST_ITEM] Occasional teratomas contain tissues from only two germ layers
[LIST_ITEM] Rare teratomas contain tissues from only one germ layer (monodermal teratomas).
[LIST_ITEM] Most common example of the latter in the ovary is struma ovarii (thyroid)
[LIST_ITEM] Usually occur in children and young adults
[LIST_ITEM] May be encountered throughout reproductive life
[LIST_ITEM] Dermoid cyst, show squamous epithelium, sebaceous glands, fat, and cartilage
(a) Torsion that may lead to one or more of infarction, perforation, hemoperitoneum, and autoamputation

(c) spontaneous perforation into the peritoneal cavity or a hollow viscus; a sudden rupture may lead to an acute abdomen, whereas a slow leak may lead to a granulomatous peritonitis that can mimic metastatic carcinoma or tuberculosis at operation
(d) hemolytic anemia that disappears after removal of the tumor.

>95% of dermoid cysts are benign, but rarely they are complicated by the development of a cancer that can arise from any component of the dermoid cyst (or a mature solid teratoma), but in most cases it is a squamous cell carcinoma that arises from the squamous lining of the cyst showing both in situ
[right] and invasive [left] squamous cell carcinoma arising in a dermoid cyst).
The risk of malignant transformation of a component of a dermoid cyst increases with the age of the patient, and is most likely to be found in a dermoid cyst in a postmenopausal woman.
In such cases, the dermoid cyst probably arose years earlier, but did not clinically present until after the menopause.
If the cancer has spread beyond the ovary at the time of its removal, the prognosis is poor.
[LIST_ITEM] Dermoid cyst, for example, may be associated with a malignant germ cell tumor. Most common of such tumors is the dysgerminoma
[LIST_ITEM] Ovarian analogue of the testicular seminoma
[LIST_ITEM] Sheets of tumor cells resembling primordial-type germ cells
[LIST_ITEM] Separated by a stroma rich in lymphocytes
[LIST_ITEM] Dermoid cysts need to be examined carefully
[LIST_ITEM] Associated malignant germ cell tumor (usually in a child or young adult),
[LIST_ITEM] Cancer arising from a component of the dermoid cyst, usually squamous cell carcinoma, in an older patient.
[LIST_ITEM] From the sex cord-type cells in the ovary
[LIST_ITEM] Granulosa cells - giving rise to granulosa cell tumors - estrogen producing
[LIST_ITEM] Theca cells - giving rise to thecomas - estrogen producing
[LIST_ITEM] Fibroblastic stromal cells of the ovary - giving rise to fibromas – no func.
[LIST_ITEM] Rare tumors exhibit differentiation into testicular type cells - Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors - androgenic.
[LIST_ITEM] Large mass and resembles a primary tumor - "Krukenberg" tumor
[LIST_ITEM] Usually is metastatic from a primary in gastrointestinal tract
[LIST_ITEM] Usually GI tract (especially colon and stomach) and breast, but almost any primary tumor in the body can spread to the ovaries
[LIST_ITEM] Implants of tumor on the serosal surface of the ovarian tumors
[LIST_ITEM] Histologic resemblance of the ovarian tumor to the primary tumor
